issues.description: The problem description instructs students to initialize SealSaloon attributes (orders and stock) in the constructor (constructor takes no parameters) but also states that the stock attribute must be static (shared across all instances). Initializing a static (and especially a static final) field in an instance constructor is incorrect: static final fields must be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer, and assigning to a static final in an instance constructor will not compile. The solution resolves this by declaring and initializing stock as a static final field at declaration, which conflicts with the phrasing in the problem text and would confuse students about where/how to initialize stock.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify and make the instructions consistent: either (A) require stock to be an instance final field and instruct students to initialize it in the (no-arg) constructor, or (B) require stock to be static (shared) and instruct students to initialize it at declaration or in a static initializer. Update the problem text to explicitly state the chosen approach (e.g., "stock must be declared static final and initialized at declaration or in a static initializer, not in the instance constructor").

issues.description: The UML/problem statement shows totalOrders as an int ("-totalOrders: int") while the solution implementation declares totalOrders as a long. This is a mismatch in the expected attribute type and could confuse students about the intended type to use for tracking total orders.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type consistent across the specification and implementation. Either change the UML/problem text to indicate totalOrders: long (if larger range is desired) or change the solution implementation to use int to match the UML. Also update any related documentation or tests to reflect the chosen type.
